Crowly, ed., African Folklore in the New World (Austin: University of Texas Press, 1977); Roger D. Abrahams, ed., Afro-American Folktales: Stories from Black Traditions in the New World (New York: Pantheon, 1985); William Bascom, African Folktales in the New World (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1992); and Dickson D.             86	See Michael A. Elliott, The Culture Concept: Writing and Difference in the Age of Realism (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2002); Brad Evans, Before Cultures: The Ethnographic Imagination in American Literature, 1865–1920 (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2005); and Bill Brown, A Sense of Things: The Object Matter of American Literature (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2003).
          
          
            87	In What Is Posthumanism? (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2010), Cary Wolfe argues that posthumanism must entail the troubling of both humanist form (the assumption that there is a natural, one-to-one correspondence between the representation and the represented) and humanist content (the taxonomic privileging of the human over the nonhuman).
          
          
            88	For the relation of these movements and Africanist beliefs, see Anderson, Conjure, 140–42.
          
          
            89	Although this conception owes much to British romanticism, both Muir and Burroughs were inspired more directly by Emerson, Thoreau, and Whitman. Indeed, Burroughs wrote the first biography on Whitman, Notes on Walt Whitman as Poet and Person (1867). In the later Birds and Poets (the title resonating with Whitmanian echoes), he characteristically claimed that “the true poet knows more about Nature than the naturalists because he carries her open secrets in his heart.” http://wakerobin.org/.
          
          
            90	H. P. Blavatsky, The Secret Doctrine: The Synthesis of Science, Religion, and Philosophy, vol. I, Cosmogenesis (1888; repr., Pasadena, Calif.: Theosophical University Press, 1952), 268, 445. See also Richard Maurice Bucke’s Cosmic Consciousness: A Study in the Evolution of the Human Mind (1901; repr., New York: E. P. Dutton, 1967), which, quoting from Dante, contends that the cosmically conscious person is “‘transhumanized into a God’” (75; my emphasis).
          
          
            91	Mechal Sobel, Trabelin’ On: The Slave Journey to an Afro-Baptist Faith
